prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Lost credit card replaced with new card and new numbers. Credit score affected?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, replacing a lost credit card can potentially affect your credit score. When you report a lost credit card to your issuer, they will typically issue you a new card with new numbers. This can cause a slight decline in your credit score, as the new card may not have an existing credit history or payment pattern.

The impact on your credit score will depend on various factors, including the length of time you've had the card, your payment history, and the amount of credit available to you. If the lost card had a long history of responsible payments, the impact may be minimal. However, if you've recently applied for the card or your payment history is less than perfect, the change in credit card numbers may result in a temporary dip in your credit score.

It's important to note that the change in credit card numbers is a temporary and temporary occurrence, and your credit score will likely return to normal once the new card is reported to the credit bureaus. This can take several months, as the new card information will have to be reflected in your credit report and updated by the credit bureaus.

In the meantime, it's essential to continue making timely payments and managing your credit responsibly to keep your credit score steady. You can also consider reaching out to your issuer to have the new card reported to the credit bureaus more quickly to minimize the impact on your credit score.
answers: The true answer is it depends because  it is up to the credit card issuer to follow the right path when issuing a replacement credit card. http://www.bankrate.com/finance/credit-cards/will-replacement-card-hurt-my-score.aspx Typically, issuers will transfer the account history to the new trade line, says Barry Paperno, the consumer operations manager at FICO, the creator of the FICO scoring formula. The new account should have the old open date, so you should retain your payment history, he says. The credit limit and balance should also stay the same. http://blog.credit.com/2014/02/lost-or-stolen-credit-card-hurt-your-credit-scores-76724/ How Issuers Report Replacement Cards We asked the major card issuers how they report replacement cards to credit reporting agencies: American Express: The new card has the same open date and “Member Since” year as the previous card. The balance on the old account number is transferred to the new account number. All payment history transfers over. Bank of America: All transactions and account history are transferred to the new account number when there is a card replacement or renewal. Capital One: The new account number with all the original account data (original open date, etc.) is reported along with a notification to the bureaus that the new account number is replacing the old.  The two tradelines can then be ‘merged’ into one, so that all the applicable payment history, balance, etc. is now under the new account number. Chase: The original tradeline does not change. The history on the account remains, just the account number field is updated with the new account number. There is no “new” tradeline in this scenario.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

How is your credit score related to credit utilization?[/INST]
pred:
Credit score and credit utilization are closely related concepts in the world of personal finance. Your credit score is a numerical representation of your creditworthiness, based on your credit history and credit usage. Credit utilization, on the other hand, refers to the amount of credit you are using compared to the amount of credit available to you.

In general, a low credit utilization rate is considered better for your credit score. This means that you are using a small portion of your available credit, which is seen as a positive sign by lenders. The ideal credit utilization rate is typically considered to be below 30%, although some sources may suggest a range of 10% to 20%.

When you use a large portion of your available credit, your credit utilization rate increases. This can negatively impact your credit score, as lenders may view you as a higher credit risk. High credit utilization can indicate that you are stretching yourself too thin, or that you may struggle to pay off your debts.

Conversely, a low credit utilization rate can help improve your credit score. Lenders prefer to see that you are using a small portion of your available credit, as this indicates that you are able to manage your debt responsibly. By keeping your credit utilization rate low, you can show lenders that you are a reliable borrower and are less likely to default on your debts.
answers: Curious, why are you interested in building/improving your credit score? Is it better to use your card and pay off the bill completely every month? Yes. How is credit utiltization calculated?    Is it average utilization over the month, or total amount owed/credit_limit per month? It depends on how often your bank reports your balances to the reporting agencies. It can be daily, when your statement cycle closes, or some other interval. How does credit utilization affect your score?  Closest to zero without actually being zero is best. This translates to making some charges, even $1 so your statement shows a balance each statement that you pay off. This shows as active use. If you pay off your balance before the statement closes, then it can sometimes be reported as inactive/unused. Is too much a bad thing?  Yes. Is too little a bad thing? Depends. Being debt free has its advantages... but if your goal is to raise your credit score, then having a low utilization rate is a good metric. Less than 7% utilization seems to be the optimal level.  "Last year we started using a number, not as a recommendation, but as a fact that most of the people with really high FICO scores have credit utilization rates that are 7 percent or lower," Watts said. Read more: http://www.bankrate.com/finance/credit-cards/how-to-bump-up-your-credit-score.aspx Remember that on-time payment is the most important factor. Second is how much you owe. Third is length of credit history. Maintain these factors in good standing and you will improve your score: http://www.myfico.com/CreditEducation/WhatsInYourScore.aspx

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Do dividend quotes for U.S. stocks include witheld taxes?[/INST]
pred:
Dividend quotes for U.S. stocks typically do not include withheld taxes. When you see a dividend quote, it is the per-share amount of the dividend that the company is paying out to its shareholders, without any deductions or withholdings.

The withheld taxes, also known as dividend withholding taxes, are subtracted from the dividend payment before it is distributed to shareholders. The withholding rate is typically around 25%, but it can vary depending on the company and the type of dividend being paid out.

For example, if a company declares a dividend of $1 per share and the withholding tax rate is 25%, the actual amount paid to shareholders would be $0.75 per share ($1 - $0.25 withholding tax).

It's important to note that the withheld taxes are not deducted from the dividend quote itself, but rather from the actual dividend payment. Therefore, when you see a dividend quote, you should assume that the amount listed is the total amount that you will receive, without any deductions or withholdings.

It's always a good idea to review the dividend declaration and check for any additional withholding taxes or deductions that may apply, as these can vary depending on your
answers: The dividend quoted on a site like the one you linked to on Yahoo shows what 1 investor owning 1 share received from the company. It is not adjusted at all for taxes. (Actually some dividend quotes are adjusted but not for taxes... see below.)  It is not adjusted because most dividends are taxed as ordinary income. This means different rates for different people, and so for simplicity's sake the quotes just show what an investor would be paid.  You're responsible for calculating and paying your own taxes.  From the IRS website: Ordinary Dividends Ordinary (taxable) dividends are the most common type of distribution from a corporation or a mutual fund. They are paid out of earnings and profits and are ordinary income to you. This means they are not capital gains. You can assume that any dividend you receive on common or preferred stock is an ordinary dividend unless the paying corporation or mutual fund tells you otherwise. Ordinary dividends will be shown in box 1a of the Form 1099-DIV you receive. Now my disclaimer... what you see on a normal stock quote for dividend in Yahoo or Google Finance is adjusted. (Like here for GE.) Many corporations actually pay out quarterly dividends. So the number shown for a dividend will be the most recent quarterly dividend [times] 4 quarters. To find out what you would receive as an actual payment, you would need to divide GE's current $0.76 dividend by 4 quarters... $0.19. So you would receive that amount for each share of stock you owned in GE.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Is it possible to block previously authorized ACH access?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, it is possible to block previously authorized ACH access. The National Automated Clearing House Association (NACHA) Rule 31 requires financial institutions to provide customers with the ability to request the return of previously authorized ACH transactions. This is known as "ACH Return Requests."

To block previously authorized ACH access, a customer must submit an ACH return request to their bank, providing the ACH transaction ID, the date of the transaction, and the reason for the return. The bank will then process the request and return the funds to the customer's account.

It's important to note that ACH returns are not immediate, and it may take several days for the funds to be returned to the customer's account. Additionally, some businesses may have a delay in processing ACH returns, which can impact the timing of the return.

It's also worth mentioning that blocking previously authorized ACH access does not necessarily prevent future ACH transactions from being processed. If a customer wants to prevent future ACH transactions from being processed altogether, they will need to contact their bank and request that their account be closed or placed on hold.

In summary, while it is possible to block previously authorized ACH access, it's important to understand the process and any potential delays or limitations that may apply. Customers should also be aware of their options for preventing future ACH

answers: When you want to invest in an asset denominated by a foreign currency, your investment is going to have some currency risk to it. You need to worry not just about what happens to your own currency, but also the foreign currency. Lets say you want to invest $10000 in US Stocks as a Canadian. Today that will cost you $13252, since USDCAD just hit 1.3252. You now have two ways you can make money. One is if USDCAD goes up, two is if the stocks go up. The former may not be obvious, but remember, you are holding US denominated assets currently, with the intention of one day converting those assets back into CAD. Essentially, you are long USDCAD (long USD short CAD). Since you are short CAD, if CAD goes up it hurts you It may seem odd to think about this as a currency trade, but it opens up a possibility. If you want a foreign investment to be currency neutral, you just make the opposite currency trade, in addition to your original investment. So in this case, you would buy $10,000 in US stocks, and then short USDCAD (ie long CAD, short USD $10,000). This is kind of savvy and may not be something you would do. But its worth mentioning. And there are also some currency hedged ETFs out there that do this for you http://www.ishares.com/us/strategies/hedge-currency-impact However most are hedged relative to USD, and are meant to hedge the target countries currency, not your own.

Should I always pay my credit at the last day possible to maximize my savings interest?[/INST]

Paying off credit card balances at the last day possible to maximize savings interest can be a good strategy in some cases, but it's not always the best option. Here are some things to consider:

Interest rates: If you have a high-interest credit card balance, paying it off as soon as possible can help you save money on interest charges. This is especially true if you have a promotional offer with a low or 0% introductory APR that's about to expire. In this case, it's better to pay off the balance before the promotional period ends to avoid paying higher interest rates.

Fees: Some credit cards come with fees for late payments or exceeding your credit limit. If you're chronically late with payments, it may be better to set up automatic payments to avoid these fees.

Credit utilization: Paying off your credit card balance in full each month can help you maintain a low credit utilization ratio, which is the amount of available credit you're using compared to the total limit. A low utilization ratio (less than 30%) can help improve your credit score.

Breakage fees: If you're paying off a credit card balance that's tied to a brokerage account or another financial product, there may be breakage fees associated with early withdraw

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Using stop-loss as risk management: Is it safe?[/INST]
pred:
Stop-loss insurance is a risk management tool that enables investors to limit their potential losses in a given investment. It works by setting a minimum price at which an investment can be sold, above which the investor will incur a loss. By using a stop-loss order, investors can guard against significant losses in their portfolio due to market volatility or unforeseen events.

The safety of using stop-losses depends on several factors, including the type of investment, the investor's risk tolerance, and the market conditions. In general, stop-losses can be a useful tool in managing risk, but they are not foolproof. Here are some potential risks to consider:

1. Price fluctuations: The price of an investment may fall below the stop-loss level due to market fluctuations, even if the underlying fundamentals of the investment are strong. In such cases, the stop-loss order may be triggered, resulting in a loss.
2. Market volatility: In highly volatile markets, stop-loss orders may be triggered more frequently, leading to excessive trading activity and potential losses.
3. Gapping: In some cases, the price of an investment may gap below the stop-loss level, resulting in a larger loss than anticipated.
4. Market events: Unforeseen market events
answers: A stop-loss order becomes a market order when a trade has occurred at or below the trigger price you set when creating the order. This means that you could possibly end up selling some or all of your position at a price lower than your trigger price. For relatively illiquid securities your order may be split into transactions with several buyers at different prices and you could see a significant drop in price between the first part of the order and the last few shares. To mitigate this, brokers also offer a stop-limit order, where you set not only a trigger price, but also a minimum price that you are will to accept for your shares. This reduces the risk of selling at rock bottom prices, especially if you are selling a very large position. However, in the case of a flash crash where other sellers are driving the price below your limit, that part of your order may never execute and you could end up being stuck with a whole lot of shares that are worth less than both your stop loss trigger and limit price. For securities that are liquid and not very volatile, either option is a pretty safe way to cut your losses. For securities that are illiquid and/or very volatile a stop-limit order will prevent you from cashing out at bottom dollar and giving away a bargain to lurkers hanging out at the bottom of the market, but you may end up stuck with shares you don't want for longer than originally planned. It's up to you to decide which kind of risk you prefer.

Can another tax loss be used to offset capital gains taxes? How does it work?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, another tax loss can be used to offset capital gains taxes through a process called "tax loss harvesting." Tax loss harvesting involves selling an investment that has declined in value to realize a loss, which can be used to offset capital gains from the sale of another investment. By doing so, you can reduce your tax liability on the capital gains from the second investment.

Here's how it works:

1. Identify investments that have declined in value: Review your investment portfolio to identify investments that have lost value compared to their original purchase price. These investments are called "tax loss positions."
2. Sell the tax loss positions: Sell the investments that are in tax loss positions to realize the losses. You can sell them through a broker or directly through the financial institution where you hold them.
3. Use the losses to offset capital gains: Once you have realized the losses, you can use them to offset capital gains from other investments. For example, if you sold an investment for a gain of $1,000, you could use a $500 loss from another investment to reduce your tax liability by $500.
4. Carry over excess losses: If you have more losses than gains to offset, you can carry over the excess losses to future years. There is no
answers: Capital losses do mirror capital gains within their holding periods. An asset or investment this is certainly held for a year into the day or less, and sold at a loss, will create a short-term capital loss. A sale of any asset held for over a year to your day, and sold at a loss, will create a loss that is long-term. When capital gains and losses are reported from the tax return, the taxpayer must first categorize all gains and losses between long and short term, and then aggregate the sum total amounts for every single regarding the four categories. Then the gains that are long-term losses are netted against each other, therefore the same is done for short-term gains and losses. Then your net gain that is long-term loss is netted against the net short-term gain or loss. This final net number is then reported on Form 1040. Example Frank has the following gains and losses from his stock trading for the year: Short-term gains - $6,000 Long-term gains - $4,000 Short-term losses - $2,000 Long-term losses - $5,000 Net short-term gain/loss - $4,000 ST gain ($6,000 ST gain - $2,000 ST loss) Net long-term gain/loss - $1,000 LT loss ($4,000 LT gain - $5,000 LT loss) Final net gain/loss - $3,000 short-term gain ($4,000 ST gain - $1,000 LT loss)   Again, Frank can only deduct $3,000 of final net short- or long-term losses against other types of income for that year and must carry forward any remaining balance.

You can also request a payment plan or negotiate a settlement amount that works for you.

Be sure to have your account number and other relevant information handy to make the payment process as smooth as possible.

In summary, paying your medical bill directly to the hospital is a viable option to avoid additional fees and penalties, and may even help improve your credit score

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Is a debt collector allowed to make a hard inquiry on your credit report?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, a debt collector is legally allowed to make a hard inquiry on your credit report when attempting to collect a debt. A hard inquiry is a type of inquiry that appears on your credit report when a lender or debt collectoraccesses your credit information. This type of inquiry indicates that someone has requested your credit report for a specific purpose, such as evaluating a credit application or verifying the existence of a debt.

Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA), debt collectors are considered "creditors" and are allowed to make hard inquiries on your credit report in order to verify the existence of a debt and your payment history. This allows them to determine whether you have an outstanding debt and whether you have made any payments towards it.

It's important to note that debt collectors are only allowed to make hard inquiries on your credit report for the purpose of collecting a debt that you owe. They cannot use your credit report for any other purpose, such as determining your eligibility for credit or employment.

Additionally, debt collectors are required to follow certain procedures when making a hard inquiry on your credit report. They must provide you with a clear and conspicuous disclosure that they are accessing your credit report, and they must also inform you of your rights under the FCRA.
answers: According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act: any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report [...] to a person which it has reason to believe [...] intends to use the information in connection with a credit transaction involving the consumer on whom the information is to be furnished and   involving the extension of credit to, or review or collection of an account of, the consumer See p12 (section 604). The usual interpretation of this that I've heard is that a debt collection agency that owns or has been assigned a debt can make hard pulls on your credit report without your consent. This link seems to support that (and references the same part of the act, among others): According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act, [...], any business can access your credit history without your permission provided the business has a valid "permissible purpose." The FCRA notes that one such permissible purpose is to review your credit information in connection with the collection of a debt. Thus, if you owe money to a debt collector, the debt collector has the legal right to pull and review your credit report. If they haven't been assigned the debt or own it outright, I believe you have a legal right to dispute it. Consult a lawyer if this is actually a situation you face.  Once use for this is if the debt collection agency has trouble locating you; since your credit report normally contains current and past addresses, this is one way to locate you.

answers: There are many reasons, which other answers have already discussed. I want to emphasize and elaborate on just one of the reasons, which is that it avoids double taxation, especially on corporate earnings.  Generally, for corporations, its earnings are already taxed at around 40% (for the US - including State income taxes). When dividends are distributed out, it is taxed again at the individual level. The effect is the same when equity is sold and the distribution is captured as a capital gain. (I believe this is why the dividend and capital gain rates are the same in the US.) For a simplistic example, say there is a C Corporation with a single owner. The company earns $1,000,000 before income taxes. It pays 400,000 in taxes, and has retained earnings of $600,000. To get the money out, the owner can either distribute a dividend to herself, or sell her stake to another person. Either choice leads to $600,000 getting taxed at another 20%~30% or so at the individual level (depending on the State). If we calculate the effective rate, it is above 50%! Many people invest in stock, including mutual funds, and the dividends and capital gains are taxed at lower rates. Individual tax returns that contain no wage income often have very low average tax rates for this reason. However, the investments themselves are continuously paying out their own taxes, or accruing taxes in the form of future tax liability.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

What is the difference between a stop order and a stop limit order?[/INST]
pred:
A stop order and a stop limit order are two types of order types used by traders in financial markets. While they seem similar, there are key differences between the two.

A stop order, also known as a stop loss order, is an order to buy or sell a security when its price reaches a certain level, known as the stop price. The main purpose of a stop order is to limit potential losses by closing a position at a specific price. For example, a trader might place a stop order to sell 100 shares of XYZ stock at $50 per share to limit potential losses if the stock price drops. The stop order becomes a market order once the stock price reaches the specified level, and the trade is executed at the next available price.

On the other hand, a stop limit order is an order to buy or sell a security when its price reaches a certain level, but only at a specific price level. A stop limit order combines the features of a stop order and a limit order. With a stop limit order, the trader sets a price level at which they are willing to buy or sell the security, but the order will only be executed at that specific price or better. For example, a trader might place a stop limit order to buy 100 shares of XYZ stock at $55 per share, but the order will only be executed if the stock price reaches $55
answers: An attempt at a simple answer for the normal investor: A normal investor buys stock then later sells that stock. (This is known as "going long", as opposed to "going short").  For the normal investor, a stop order (of either kind) is only used when selling. A stop-loss sell order (or stop sell) is used to sell your stock when it has fallen too much in price, and you don't want to suffer more losses.  If the stock is at $50, you could enter a stop sell at $40, which means if the stock ever falls to $40 or lower, your stock will be sold at whatever price is available (e.g. $35). A stop-loss limit sell order (or stop limit sell) is the same, except you are also saying "but don't sell for less than my limit price".  So you can enter a stop limit sell at $40 with a limit of $39, meaning that if the stock falls to $40, you will then have a limit order in effect to sell the stock at $39 or higher.  Thus your stock will never be sold at $35 or any value below $39, but of course, if the stock falls fast from $40 to $35, your limit sell at $39 will not be done and you will be left still owning the stock (worth at that moment $35, say).

This amount of income at which you are required to file depends on several things, including your dependency status (you are a dependent of your parents), your marital status, and other factors. A related hedge is a financial instrument used to manage financial risks, particularly those arising from changes in interest rates, currencies, or commodity prices. The primary purpose of a related hedge is to establish a predictable financial position by offsetting potential losses or gains in an underlying investment.

There are several types of related hedges, each designed to address specific risks. For example:

1. Interest Rate Hedge: This type of hedge is used to manage interest rate risk, which can affect the value of fixed-income investments. An interest rate hedge involves locking in a fixed interest rate for a loan or bond, which can help protect against potential changes in market interest rates.
2. Currency Hedge: A currency hedge is used to manage exchange rate risks that can arise when investing in foreign markets. By converting the value of an investment from one currency to another, the hedge helps protect against changes in exchange rates that could negatively impact the investment's value.
3. Commodity Hedge: This type of hedge is used to manage price risks associated with commodity investments. A commodity hedge involves buying or selling a futures contract in a commodity index, such as gold or oil, to protect against potential price movements in the underlying commodity.
4. Dividend H
answers: In this type of strategy profit is made when the shares go down as your main position is the short trade of the common stock. Since both the bonds and the preference shares are higher on the list to be repaid if the company declares bankruptcy and the bonds pay out a fixed amount of interest as well, both also help protect against problems that may occur with a long position in the common stock. prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

“Convertible -debt/note/bond/debentures” which of these are the same or different?[/INST]
pred:
Convertible debt, notes, bonds, and debentures are all financial instruments that allow investors to invest in a company with the potential for financial returns. While they share some similarities, there are also some key differences between these instruments.

A convertible debt is a type of debt instrument that can be converted into a predetermined amount of equity in the underlying company at a future date, usually at the option of the investor. For example, a company may issue a convertible bond that can be converted into shares of the company's common stock at a later date. Convertible debt is often used by companies to raise capital without giving up ownership, as the debt can be converted into equity if the company performs well.

A note, on the other hand, is a type of debt instrument that has a fixed interest rate and a predetermined repayment schedule. Notes are typically issued by companies to raise capital and can be unsecured or secured by assets. Unlike convertible debt, notes do not typically have a conversion feature, meaning they cannot be converted into equity.

A bond is a type of long-term debt security that represents a loan made by an investor to a corporation or government. Bonds typically have a fixed interest rate and a predetermined repayment schedule, with the investor receiving regular interest payments and the return
answers: They all basically mean the same thing - a type of debt than can be exchanged for (converted into) equity at some point. It's only the mechanics that can be different. A convertible bond is structured just like a regular bond - it (usually) pays periodic interest and has a face value that's due at maturity. The difference is that the bond holder has the option to exchange the debt for equity at some point during the life of the bond.  There can be restrictions on when that conversion is possible, and they typically define a quantity of equity (number of shares) that the bond can be converted into.  If the market price of the shares goes above a price that would make the shares more valuable than the bond, it's in the best interest of the bond holder to convert. A convertible note is typically used to describe a kind of startup financing that does not pay interest or have a face value that's redeemed, but instead is redeemed for equity as part of a later financing round.  Rather than specifying a specific number of shares, the bond holder receives equity at a certain discount to the rest of the market. So they both are debt instruments that can turn into equity investments, just through different mechanisms. A debenture is a fancy word for unsecured debt, and convertible debt could be used to described either structure above, so those terms could mean either type of structure.

To avoid these charges, it's crucial to keep track of your credit card usage and make timely payments to avoid going over your credit limit.

answers: The best answer to this is: Read the fine print on your credit card agreement. What is common, at least in the US, is that you can make any charges you want during a time window. answers: There is certainly an obligation in some cases of a company to distribute profit, either as dividend or a stock buy back. Activist investors frequently push for one or the other when a company is doing well - sometimes to the detriment of future growth, in some eyes - and can even file shareholder lawsuits (saying the company is not doing its duty to its shareholders by simply holding onto cash).  Apple famously held out from doing either for years under Steve Jobs, and only in the last few years started doing both - a large dividend and a share buy-back which increases the value of remaining shares (as EPS then goes up with fewer shares out there). Companies in their growth phase often don't return any money and simply reinvest - but the long-term hope is to either return money in the form of dividends on profits, or the sale of the company.

answers: A huge amount of money in all financial markets is from institutional investors, such as mutual funds, government pension plans, sovereign wealth funds, etc.  For various reasons these funds do all of their trading at the end of the day.  They care primarily that their end-of-day balances are in line with their targets and are easy to audit and far less about "timing the market" for the best possible trades. So, if you're looking at a stock that is owned by many institutional investors -- such as a stock (like AAPL) that makes up a significant portion of an index that many funds track -- there will be a huge amount of activity at this time relative to stocks that are less popular among institutions. (In fact, because of all this closing activity and the reliance on end-of-day prices as signposts for financial calculations, the end-of-day has for decades been the single most fraud-ridden time of the trading day.  Electronic trading has done away with a lot of the straight-up thievery that floor traders and brokers used to get away with at the expense of the public, but it still exists.  See, for example, any explanation of the term banging the close, or the penalties against 6 banks just last month for manipulating the FX market at the close.)

answers: The Creation/Redemption mechanism is how shares of an ETF are created or redeemed as needed and thus is where there can be differences in what the value of the holdings can be versus the trading price. If the ETF is thinly traded, then the difference could be big as more volume would be where the mechanism could kick in as generally there are blocks required so the mechanism usually created or redeemed in lots of 50,000 shares I believe. From the link where AP=Authorized Participant: With ETFs, APs do most of the buying and selling. When APs sense   demand for additional shares of an ETF—which manifests itself when the   ETF share price trades at a premium to its NAV—they go into the market   and create new shares. When the APs sense demand from investors   looking to redeem—which manifests itself when the ETF share price   trades at a discount—they process redemptions. So, suppose the NAV of the ETF is $20/share and the trading price is $30/share. The AP can buy the underlying securities for $20/share in a bulk order that equates to 50,000 shares of the ETF and exchange the underlying shares for new shares in the ETF. Then the AP can turn around and sell those new ETF shares for $30/share and pocket the gain. If you switch the prices around, the AP would then take the ETF shares and exchange them for the underlying securities in the same way and make a profit on the difference. SEC also notes this same process.

How do UK Gilts interest rates and repayments work?[/INST]
pred:
UK gilts are a type of government bond issued by the British government to raise funds from investors. The interest rates on gilts are determined by the market forces of supply and demand, and are influenced by a variety of factors, including inflation expectations, economic growth, and monetary policy.

The repayment structure of gilts varies depending on the maturity date of the bond. For example, shorter-term gilts typically have a fixed coupon rate (interest rate) that is paid semi-annually, while longer-term gilts may have a floating coupon rate that is reset periodically based on market conditions.

Investors purchase gilts at a discount to their face value, which means they earn the difference between the purchase price and the face value in the form of interest payments over the life of the bond. For example, if an investor purchases a £1,000 gilt at a discount of 95%, they will receive £1,000 in interest payments over the life of the bond, while the government will repay the face value of £1,000 at maturity.

Gilt interest rates are benchmarked against the Bank of England's base rate, which is set by the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) of the Bank of England. The MPC uses the
answers: The name of the Gilt states the redemption date, but not the original issue date. A gilt with 8.75% yield and close to its redemption date may have been issued at a time when interest rates were indeed close to 8.75%. For example in the early 1990s, the UK inflation rate was about 8%. One reason for preferring high or low coupon gilts is the trade off between capital gains and income, and the different taxation rules for each. If you buy a gilt and hold it to its maturity date, you know in advance the exact price that it will be redeemed for (i.e. £100). You may prefer to take a high level of income now, knowing you will make a capital loss in future (which might offset some other predictable capital gain for tax purposes) or you may prefer not to take income that you don't need right now, and instead get a guaranteed capital gain in future (for example, when you plan to retire from work). Also, you can use the change in the market value of gilts as a gamble or a hedge against your expectation of interest rate changes in future, with the "government guaranteed" fallback position that if your predictions are wrong, you know exactly what return you will get if you hold the gilts to maturity. The same idea applies to other bond investments - but without the government guarantee, of course.

answers: A UTMA may or may not fit your situation. The main drawbacks to a UTMA account is that it will count against your child for financial aid (it counts as the child's asset). The bid price is the highest price that a buyer is willing to pay for a security, while the ask price is the lowest price that a seller is willing to accept. In a typical stock transaction, the bid price is typically lower than the ask price, creating a spread or differential between the two prices. This differential represents the profit that the seller hopes to make on the sale of the security.

If you are interested in purchasing a security at a lower price than the ask price, you can do so by using a purchase order that is below the ask price. This is known as buying at the bid price or below. For example, if the ask price for a stock is $50 and you are willing to pay $40, you can place an order to buy the stock at $40. If the order is filled, you will pay $40 for the stock, while the seller will receive $50, resulting in a $10 profit.

There are several benefits to buying at the bid price or below, including:

1. Lower cost basis: By paying a lower price for the security, your cost basis will be lower, which can reduce your tax liability if the security increases in value.

answers: In addition to the other answers, here's a proper strategy that implements your idea: If the options are priced properly they should account for future dividend payments, so all other things aside, a put option that is currently at the money should be in the money after the dividend, and hence more expensive than a put option that is out of the money today but at the money after the dividend has been paid. The unprotected futures (if priced correctly) should account for dividend payments based on the dividend history and, since maturing after the payment, should earn you (you sell them) less money because you deliver the physical after the dividend has been paid. The protected ones should reflect the expected total return value of the stock at the time of maturity (i.e. the dividend is mentally calculated into the price), and any dividend payments that happen on the way will be debited from your cash (and credited to the counterparty). Now that's the strategy that leaves you with nearly no risk (the only risk you bear is that the dividend isn't as high as you expected).  But for that comfort you have to pay premiums. prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Are wash sale rules different for stocks and ETFs / Mutual Funds?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, wash sale rules are different for stocks, exchange-traded funds (ETFs), and mutual funds. The wash sale rule is a tax rule that aims to prevent investors from deducting losses on investments more quickly than they are allowed to realize the gains.

For stocks, the wash sale rule states that if an investor sells a security at a loss and repurchases the same or substantially identical security within 30 days before or after the sale, the loss may be disallowed for tax purposes. This is known as a "wash sale." The purpose of the rule is to prevent investors from abusing the loss deduction by merely buying the security back after a decline in value.

ETFs and mutual funds, on the other hand, are treated differently under the wash sale rule. Unlike stocks, wash sales for ETFs and mutual funds are calculated based on the average cost basis of the fund, rather than the specific security. This means that if an investor sells a fund at a loss and buys a substantially identical fund within 30 days, the loss may be disallowed for tax purposes. However, if the investor buys a different ETF or mutual fund that tracks the same index or has similar investment objectives, the wash sale rule does not apply.

It'
answers: The IRS rules are actually the same.  26 U.S. Code § 1091 - Loss from wash sales of stock or securities In   the case of any loss claimed to have been sustained from any sale or   other disposition of shares of stock or securities where it appears   that, within a period beginning 30 days before the date of such sale   or disposition and ending 30 days after such date, the taxpayer has   acquired (by purchase or by an exchange on which the entire amount of   gain or loss was recognized by law), or has entered into a contract or   option so to acquire, substantially identical stock or securities,   then no deduction shall be allowed... What you should take away from the quote above is "substantially identical stock or securities." With stocks, one company may happen to have a high correlation, Exxon and Mobil come to mind, before their merger of course. With funds or ETFs, the story is different. The IRS has yet to issue rules regarding what level of overlap or correlation makes two funds or ETFs "substantially identical."  Last month, I wrote an article, Tax Loss Harvesting, which analyses the impact of taking losses each year. I study the 2000's which showed an average loss of 1% per year, a 9% loss for the decade. Tax loss harvesting made the decade slightly positive, i.e. an annual boost of approx 1%.

Are capitalization rate and net profit margin the same thing?[/INST]
pred:
No, capitalization rate and net profit margin are not the same thing, although they are related to each other.

Capitalization rate, also known as cap rate, is a financial metric used to evaluate the potential return on investment in a real estate property. It is calculated by dividing the property's net operating income (NOI) by its purchase price or estimated value. The resulting percentage represents the annual return on investment, expressed as a dollars-for-dollars ratio. For example, if a property has an NOI of $100,000 and a purchase price of $1,000,000, the capitalization rate would be 10% ($100,000 / $1,000,000 = 0.10).

Net profit margin, on the other hand, is a financial metric used to evaluate a company's profitability. It is calculated by dividing the company's net income (profits) by its revenue. The resulting percentage represents the percentage of revenue that the company retains as profit, after deducting all expenses. If house A costs $1M and you'll make $50K (profit) from it yearly, and house B costs $1.33M and you'll make $65K (profit) from it yearly, then you can compute cap rates to see that A is a more efficient investment from the point of view of income vs. amount-of-money-you-have-stuck-in-this-investment-and-unavailable-for-use-elsewhere. prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

How much is one “lot” of EUR/USD?[/INST]
pred:
A "lot" of EUR/USD is a unit of measurement used in the foreign exchange market to describe a standardized amount of currency. The standard lot size for the EUR/USD pair is 100,000 units of the base currency (Euros) denominated in the quote currency (United States Dollars). This means that if you buy or sell 1 lot of EUR/USD, you will be trading 100,000 euros worth of currency.

For example, if the EUR/USD exchange rate is 1.2000, and you buy 1 lot of EUR/USD, you will be buying 100,000 euros at a price of 1.2000 dollars per euro. This means you will have paid $120,000 for your 100,000 euros. Similarly, if the exchange rate is 1.2000 and you sell 1 lot of EUR/USD, you will be selling 100,000 euros at a price of 1.2000 dollars per euro, and you will receive $120,000 for your 100,000 euros.

It's worth noting that lot sizes can
answers: A lot (sometimes called a round lot) always refers to the quantity of physical good that you're getting, like a carton of eggs or a barrel of oil.  The tricky thing in the case of forex is that the physical good also happens to be a currency. A spot currency product trades in the denomination on the right-hand side (RHS) of the product name.  So if you're buying EUR/USD you are paying USD currency to get EUR "units", and if you're selling EUR/USD you are receiving USD by giving away EUR "units".  The EUR is the "physical good" in this case. The way I remember it is to think of all products (not just currencies) as trading pairs.  So AAPL in my mind is AAPL/USD.  When I buy AAPL/USD I am paying USD to get AAPL units.  When I sell AAPL/USD I am receiving USD by giving away AAPL units. The thing on the left is the physical good (even if it happens to be money) that you are exchanging, and the thing on the right is the money that you are exchanging. So, when I buy a lot of AAPL, I am buying 100 shares at their current price in dollars. Similarly, when I buy a lot of EUR/USD, I am buying 100K Euros at their current price in dollars.

Are RSUs ever taxed as long term capital gains?[/INST]

Yes, RSUs (Restricted Stock Units) can be taxed as long-term capital gains in certain situations. Here's how it works:

When an RSU is granted, the employee receives the underlying stock or cash compensation without paying taxes on it. However, when the RSU vests and the employee sells the stock, they may be subject to taxes on the gain.

If the RSUs are held for more than one year before they are sold, they are generally considered long-term capital gains and are eligible for the lower long-term capital gains tax rate (currently up to 20%). This is in contrast to short-term capital gains, which are taxed at the ordinary income tax rate.

There are a few scenarios in which RSUs may be taxed as long-term capital gains:

1. Timing of vesting and exercise: If an RSU vests and the employee exercises it within a year of the vesting date, the gains from the sale of the stock will be considered short-term capital gains and will be taxed at the ordinary income tax rate. However, if the vesting and exercise occur more than one year after the grant date, the gains will be considered long-term capital gains.

How does the world - in aggregate - generate a non-zero return? [/INST]
pred:
The world generates a non-zero return through the concept of compounding returns. Compounding returns occur when the returns earned on an investment are reinvested, allowing the investment to earn returns on its own previous returns. This creates a snowball effect, where the returns earned in previous periods accumulate and earn additional returns over time.

For example, let's say you invest $100 in a stock that pays a 5% annual dividend. In the first year, you earn $5 in dividends, leaving you with $105. In the second year, you receive $5.25 in dividends (5% of $105), bringing your total to $110.25. This process continues year after year, with the returns earned in previous years accumulating and earning additional returns.

Over time, the compounding effect can be significant. According to the rule of 72, an investment earning a constant 5% annual return will double in value every 14.4 years. This means that after 30 years, an initial investment of $100 would be worth around $200,000, assuming the same 5% annual return.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

What is a subsidy?[/INST]
pred:
A subsidy is a financial assistance provided by a government or organization to encourage or support a particular activity, industry, or group of people. Subsidies are often used to promote economic growth, improve social welfare, or protect domestic industries.

Subsidies can take various forms, including:

1. Direct subsidies: These are direct payments made to individuals or organizations. For example, farmers may receive subsidies for producing certain crops, or homeowners may receive subsidies for energy-efficient renovations.
2. Indirect subsidies: These are subsidies that are not directly paid to individuals or organizations but instead reduce the cost of a particular product or service. For example, tax breaks for businesses can be considered an indirect subsidy, as they reduce the cost of doing business and can encourage companies to invest in certain industries.
3. Tariffs and trade barriers: These are subsidies that are imposed on imported goods to protect domestic industries. For example, a country may impose a tariff on imported steel to protect its own steel industry.

Subsidies can have both positive and negative effects on the economy. On the positive side, subsidies can:

* Stimulate economic growth by encouraging investment and innovation
* Improve social welfare by providing support to vulnerable populations
answers: A subsidy is a payment made by a group (usually the state) to individuals or corporations in order to shift the balance if the rational economic decision for the individual would be detrimental to the group as a whole otherwise. For example, if there are different quality kinds of crops that can be planted, for example a GM maize that brings in high yields but can only be processed to High Fructose Corn Syrup or a naturally bred corn that brings lower yields but tastes well enough for direct consumption, then if demand for both exceeds supply, the economic choice for the individual farmer is to plant the former. If the claims that HFCS contribute to obesity are founded, then it is in the public interest to produce less of it, and more alternative foods. Given that a market rather than a planned economy is desired, this cannot be achieved by decree, but rather money is used as an incentive. In the long term, this investment may very well pay off through reduced health care costs, so it is a rational economic decision from the state's point of view. In a world where all actors make decisions that are fully in their self interest, in principle subsidies would not be needed as consumers would demand healthy rather than cheap foods, and market mechanisms would provide these.

Yes, online gambling, particularly casino games, can be considered a bet on price fluctuations, albeit with an element of risk. In a casino, the house edge is built into the rules of each game, giving the house a theoretical advantage over the player in the long run. This means that, over time, the house is likely to win a proportion of the money wagered.

When you place a bet in a casino, you are essentially placing a wager on the outcome of a random event, such as the roll of a die or the draw of a card. The payout for each bet is determined by the odds of winning, which are set by the house. The odds are typically set to ensure that the house has a small advantage over the player, which is known as the house edge.

For example, in a game of roulette, the odds of winning are relatively low for individual bets, such as red/black or odd/even. However, the payout for these bets is relatively high, which means that if you win, you can potentially walk away with a large prize. Conversely, the odds of winning are higher for bets with lower payouts, such as individual number bets in roulette or blackjack.

So, while online gambling can be a fun and exciting way to gamble, it's important to

EBITDA, or Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization, is a financial metric commonly used in corporate finance to evaluate a company's profitability. However, there is no direct equivalent of EBITDA in personal finance.

Personal finance deals with an individual's or a household's financial decisions and activities, such as budgeting, saving, investing, and managing debt. In this context, EBITDA is not a relevant metric as it is specifically designed to assess a company's financial performance.

Instead, personal finance uses its own set of financial metrics, such as gross income, expenses, net worth, and cash flow. These metrics help individuals and households track their financial progress, make informed decisions about their money, and achieve their financial goals.

For example, to evaluate a personal budget, one might use the gross income metric to determine how much money is available for expenses, savings, and investments. Expenses, including essential expenses like housing, food, and transportation, as well as discretionary expenses like entertainment and travel, can be evaluated based on their relative importance to the individual's financial goals. Net worth, which calculates the difference between total assets and liabilities, can help individuals assess their overall financial health and progress towards their financial objectives.

Is it a bad idea to buy a motorcycle with a lien on it?[/INST]

Buying a motorcycle with a lien can be a complex decision, and it's essential to understand the potential pros and cons before making a decision. A lien is a financial obligation that a lender has on the motorcycle, which means the owner of the motorcycle has an outstanding loan that must be repaid. Here are some factors to consider:

Pros:

1. Affordability: A motorcycle with a lien may be more affordable upfront compared to buying one without a lien, as the loan payments can be spread out over time.
2. Financing options: Buying a motorcycle with a lien can provide better financing options, as the lender may offer more favorable terms than a traditional loan.
3. Credit building: Making timely payments on a lien can help build your credit score, which can be beneficial for future financing options.

Cons:

1. Ownership restrictions: When you buy a motorcycle with a lien, the lender has a claim on the vehicle until the loan is paid off. This means you may not have complete ownership of the motorcycle until the loan is satisfied.
2. Potential for negative equity: If the loan amount is higher than the motorcycle's value, you may end up with negative equity, which can make it difficult to sell the motor
answers: A lien is a mechanism to impede legal title transfer of a vehicle, real property, or sometimes, expensive business equipment.  That's why title companies exist - to make sure there are no liens against something before a buyer hands money to a seller. The lien can be attached to a loan, unpaid labor related to the item (a mechanic's lien) or unpaid taxes, and there are other scenarios where this could occur. The gist of all this is that the seller of the vehicle mentioned does not have clear title if there is a lien.  This introduces a risk for the buyer.  The buyer can pay the seller the money to cover the lien (in the case of a bank loan) but that doesn't mean the seller will actually pay off the loan (so the title is never clear!).  This article recommends visiting the bank with the seller, and getting title on-the-spot.  However, this isn't always an option, as a local bank branch isn't probably going to have the title document available, though the seller might be able to make some arrangement for a local branch to have the title available before a visit to pay off the loan. The low-risk approach is for the seller to have clear title before any money changes hands.

What is the meaning of “short selling” or “going short” a stock?[/INST]
pred:
Short selling, also known as "going short" a stock, is a financial strategy in which an investor sells a stock they do not own with the expectation of repurchasing it at a lower price to realize a profit. This is achieved by borrowing shares of the stock from a broker and selling them at the current market price, while simultaneously agreeing to buy back the same number of shares at a later date. The difference between the sale price and the purchase price represents the investor's profit.

Short selling is often used by traders and investors to profit from a decline in the price of a stock, or to hedge against potential losses in their portfolio. For example, if an investor owns a long position in a stock and believes that the stock price may fall, they can execute a short sale to offset potential losses.

It is important to note that short selling carries higher risks than long positions, as the potential losses are unlimited if the stock price rises instead of falls. In addition, short sellers are required to cover their positions at the prevailing market price, which can result in significant losses if the stock price surges.

To execute a short sale, an investor must have a margin account with a brokerage firm, which allows them to borrow shares of the stock to sell. The investor must also have sufficient funds in their account to
answers: The reason for selling a stock "short", is for when you believe the stock value will decrease in the near future. Here is an example: Today Exxon-Mobile stock is selling for $100 / share. You are expecting the price to decrease, so you want to short the stock, which means your broker (i.e. eTrade, etc) allows you to borrow shares without paying money, and those shares are transferred into your account, and then you sell them and receive money for the sale. But you didn't actually own those shares, you only borrowed them, so you need to return the shares to your broker sometime in the future.  Let's say you borrow 10 shares @ $100, and you sell them at the market price of $100, you receive $1,000 in your account. But you owe your broker 10 shares, which you need to return sometime in the future. A few days later, the share price has decreased to $80. Now you can buy 10 shares from the market at a total cost of $800. You get 10 shares, and return those shares to your broker. Since you originally took in $1,000, and you just paid out $800, you keep a resulting profit of $200

A tender offer is a financial instrument used by companies to acquire their own shares or debt securities from existing shareholders or bondholders at a specified price. Sometimes, a tender offer may be less than the current market price of the shares or bonds. There are several reasons why this might occur:

1. Cost savings: By issuing a tender offer at a lower price than the current market price, the acquiring company can save money on the acquisition cost. This is because the company does not have to pay the higher market price to purchase the shares or bonds on the open market.

3. Bid-ask spread: The price difference between the bid and ask prices on the open market can be significant, especially for illiquid or thinly traded securities. In some cases, a tender offer may be lower than the current market price due to the bid-ask spread.

answers: As an addition to Chris Rea's excellent answer, these tender offers are sometimes made specifically to cast doubt on the current market price. For instance, a large public company that contracts with a smaller supplier or service company, also public, might make a tender offer below market price. The market will look at this price and the business relationship, and wonder what the larger company knows about the smaller one that they don't. Now, what happens when investors lose confidence in a stock? They sell it, supply goes up, demand goes down, and the price drops. The company making the tender offer can then get its shares either way; directly via the offer, or on the open market. This is, however, usually not successful beyond the very short term, and typically only works because the company making a tender offer is the 800-pound gorilla, which can dictate its own terms with practically anyone else it meets. Such offers are also very closely watched by the SEC; if there's any hint that the larger company is acting in a predatory manner, or that its management is using the power and information of the company to profit themselves, the strategy will backfire as the larger company finds itself the target of SEC and DoJ legal proceedings.

Is VAT applied when a tradesman charges for materials?[/INST]
pred:
In general, Value Added Tax (VAT) is not applied when a tradesman charges for materials used in a project. VAT is a consumption tax that is levied on the value added to goods and services at each stage of production and distribution. As a tradesman charges for materials, they are not considered to be adding value to the materials themselves, but rather transferring ownership of the materials to the customer.

However, there are some exceptions to this rule. If the tradesman is also supplying VAT-able services, such as installation or maintenance, in connection with the sale of the materials, then VAT may be charged on the full price of the materials. For example, if a builder charges VAT at 20% on the cost of materials used in a construction project, and also charges VAT at 20% on the cost of installation services, then the total VAT charge will be 40% (20% on the materials and 20% on the installation services).

It's worth noting that there are also other taxes that may be applicable in addition to VAT, such as Corporation Tax for limited companies or Income Tax for self-employed individuals. Tradesmen should consult with a tax professional or accountant to ensure they are meeting their tax obligations.

In summary, VAT is not typically charged on the cost of materials used by a tr

So by the end, a total of £3 VAT is paid on the pipe (not £6.2); and at each point the business 'adding value' at that stage pays that much.  The material company adds £1 value; the producer adds £4 value; the supplier adds £5 value; the plumber adds £5 value.   Each pays some amount of VAT on that amount, typically 20% unless it's zero/reduced rated.  So the pipe supplier pays £1 but gets a £0.2 refund, so truly pays £0.8.  The plumber pays £3 (from your payment) but gets a £2 refund. According to the U.S. Tax Court and IRS guidelines, taxes must be paid based on the income earned during the tax year, which runs from January 1st to December 31st. Once the tax year has closed, the government cannot go back and tax income that was earned in a previous year.

This is due to the concept of the "statute of limitations," which sets a time limit for the IRS to assess taxes and penalties. The statute of limitations for federal income taxes is typically three years from the date the return is due or filed, whichever is later. This means that the IRS generally has three years from the end of the tax year to audit and assess taxes and penalties, but they cannot go back further than that to tax income.

There are some exceptions to this rule, such as in cases of fraud or willful failure to pay taxes, where the statute of limitations may be longer or shorter depending on the specific circumstances. However, in general, the U.S. government cannot retroactively tax gains made earlier in the fiscal year without violating the taxpayer's constitutional rights to due process and equal protection under the law.

It's important to note that tax laws and regulations
answers: You're certainly referring to "Ex Post Facto" laws, and while the US is constitutionally prohibited from passing criminal laws that are retroactive, the US Supreme Court has upheld many tax laws that apply tax code changes retroactively. You might ask a similar question on Law.SE for a more thorough treatment of the legalities of congress passing those laws, but I will stick to the personal finance portion of the question. What this means is that you can't expect that the current tax laws will be in force in the future, and your investment/retirement plans should be as flexible as possible. You may wish to have some money in both Roth and traditional 401(k) accounts. You might not want to have millions of dollars in Roth accounts, because if congress does act to limit the tax benefits of those accounts, it will probably be targeting the larger balances. If you are valuing tax deductions, you should put slightly more weight on deductions that you can take today than deductions that would apply in the future. If you do find yourself in trouble because of a retroactive change, be sure to consult a tax lawyer that specializes in dealing with the IRS to possibly negotiate a settlement for a lower amount than the full tax bill that results from the changes.

If the United States defaults on its debt, it could have significant implications for the financial system and the value of money. In the event of a default, it is possible that the value of the U.S. dollar could depreciate, leading to inflation and potentially causing a loss of purchasing power for bank deposits.

Bank deposits are generally considered to be a safe and liquid form of assets, meaning they can be easily converted into cash. However, if the U.S. government defaults on its debt, the value of these deposits could decline as investors lose confidence in the U.S. dollar and seek safer haven assets. This could lead to a bank run, where depositors withdraw their funds en masse, causing banks to face a shortage of liquidity.

In extreme cases, a government default could lead to a complete collapse of the financial system, similar to what occurred in Greece in 2015. In this scenario, it is possible that banks could freeze or even seize deposits to meet their legal obligations, such as paying back depositors in a different currency or asset.

It is worth noting that the FDIC (Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation) provides some protection for bank deposits up to $250,000 per account holder per bank. However, this protection only applies to depos

However, the fact that the governments of Russia and Argentina limited the use of cash for a period of time doesn't mean that the US government will have to do the same, it my choose some other means of restraint. What's for sure is that nothing good will happen. Nothing will probably happen to your balance in the bank (Although Cyprus has shown that that is not a given either). But I'm not so sure about FDIC maintaining it's insurance if the bank fails (meaning if the bank defaults as a result of the chain effect - you may lose your money). The Swiss stock market and the Swiss Franc (CHF) have historically exhibited a positive correlation, meaning that when the CHF appreciates, the Swiss stock market tends to perform poorly, and vice versa. However, in recent years, there has been a shift in this relationship.

According to a study by UBS, the correlation between the Swiss stock market (SPI) and the CHF has been declining since the early 2000s. In other words, the two assets are no longer as closely linked as they once were. This could be due to a variety of factors, including changes in global economic conditions, changes in central bank policies, and shifts in market sentiment.

One possible explanation for the decline in correlation is the introduction of the Swiss National Bank's (SNB) currency floor in 2011. The SNB implemented the floor to prevent the CHF from appreciating too quickly, which had been a recurring problem for the country's exports. However, this move made the CHF more predictable and less volatile, which may have reduced its impact on the stock market.

Another factor that could be contributing to the decline in correlation is the changing global economic landscape. prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

What is the opposite of Economic Bubble? [/INST]
pred:
The opposite of an economic bubble is a stable and sustainable economic environment where the market price of assets is determine by the underlying fundamental value of the asset, rather than by speculative sentiment. In a stable economy, the prices of assets, such as stocks or real estate, reflect the actual value of the underlying business or property, and do not experience sudden and unsustainable increases or decreases.

A bubble, on the other hand, occurs when the prices of assets become detached from their fundamental value and are driven instead by speculative sentiment. This can happen when investors become overly optimistic about the future prospects of an asset, and bid up the price to unsustainable levels. Eventually, the bubble bursts, and the price of the asset falls back down to its fundamental value.

In contrast, a stable economy is characterized by slow and steady economic growth, low inflation, and a consistent and sustainable increase in asset values. This allows investors to make informed decisions based on the actual value of the asset, rather than on speculative sentiment.

Some common traits of a stable economy include:

* Low inflation: A stable economy has low inflation, which means that the purchasing power of money is preserved over time.
* Consistent economic growth: A stable economy experiences steady and consistent economic growth, rather than sudden and unsustainable increases.
answers: The opposite of an economic bubble is a bubble burst :p! Jokes aside though, an economic bubble occurs when the economy is in bull market mode and asset prices are growing very fast. It's usually measured by ratio's like price to earnings and the levels of various market indices. So, the opposite would be when valuations are falling very fast or are very low, and price to earnings ratios are low.  This condition is usually a recession. A recession is a market slowdown, generally after a bubble bursts, and severe recessions can become depressions if they last long enough (Great Depression, 1930s).  A bubble is not necessarily negative - stock prices usually rise a lot so paper wealth is greatly magnified. If you can get out in time, you're golden. Similarly, a recession isn't bad for everyone. Some investors keep large amounts of cash waiting for recessions so they can "buy low, sell high". For most people, however, recessions are negative because unemployment increases and some people get fired, and the economy slows down. Asset prices have fallen so their investments are worth less than they used to be (on paper), and people mainly have to bide it out until the market starts growing again.

Yes, there is a standard check format in the United States. Checks are a common form of payment used for a variety of transactions, and the layout of the check is standardized to facilitate easy processing.

A standard check in the USA typically includes the following elements:

1. Date: The date on which the check is written.
2. Payor's Name and Address: The name and address of the person or business writing the check.
3. Payee's Name and Address: The name and address of the person or business receiving the payment.
4. Amount: The amount of the payment in both numbers and words (e.g., $100.00).
5. Check Number: A unique number assigned to the check by the payor.
6. Bank Name and Address: The name and address of the financial institution where the check is drawn.
7. Signature: The signature of the payor or a digital signature pad (for online checks).
8. Endorsement Line: A line on the back of the check for the payee to endorse the check and provide their bank's information for deposit.
9. MICR Line: A line on the bottom of the check containing the magnetic ink characters (MICR) that contain the check number, the payor's account number, and other information used for automated clearinghouse

Does the bid price of a stock change depending on which brokerage I am using?[/INST]

Yes, the bid price of a stock can change depending on which brokerage you are using. Brokerages, also known as online trading platforms, offer different prices for buying and selling stocks based on their own costs, fees, and revenues. These prices are known as bid-ask spreads, and they can vary significantly between brokerages.

The bid price is the price at which another market participant is willing to buy a stock from you, and it is typically lower than the asking price, which is the price at which you are willing to sell a stock to another market participant. The bid-ask spread represents the difference between the two prices, and it can be influenced by various factors, including market conditions, liquidity, and the reputation of the brokerage.

Some brokerages may offer lower bid prices than others due to lower operating costs or fewer financial obligations. For example, discount brokerages typically have lower fees and smaller bid-ask spreads compared to full-service brokerages. On the other hand, full-service brokerages may offer more personalized service and research tools, which can result in higher bid prices.

It's important to note that the bid price of a stock can also be influenced by market events, such as economic news, company announcements, and regulatory changes. However, the difference in bid prices between brokerages can

In general, businesses are able to accept credit card payments if they have a merchant account and comply with the rules and regulations set forth by the payment card industry (PCI). However, there are certain circumstances under which a business may be able to refuse to take credit card payments.

One reason a business may refuse to take credit cards is if they do not have a merchant account. In order to accept credit card payments, a business must have a merchant account, which is a special type of bank account that allows them to process credit card transactions. If a business does not have a merchant account, they will not be able to accept credit card payments.

Another reason a business may refuse to take credit cards is if they do not want to comply with the rules and regulations set forth by the payment card industry (PCI). These rules include requirements for data security and privacy, as well as fees associated with credit card transactions. If a business does not want to comply with these rules, they may choose to refuse to take credit card payments.

Additionally, some small businesses or sole proprietorships may choose to refuse credit card payments in order to avoid the fees associated with processing credit card transactions. These fees can be a significant portion of the sale price, and some businesses may find that it is more cost-effective to only accept cash or other forms of payment.

answers: One occastion where "will not be quoted ex" is used is when a corporate action is occurring such as a spin-off.  In such a case, the rights to, and the spin-off itself may be quoted separately on the home country exchange.  However, if the company is based abroad, it may not be worth the expense for them to have an additional securities listing on the local (US) exchange. prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

What is a negotiable security and how are they related to derivatives?[/INST]
pred:
A negotiable security is a financial instrument that can be transferred or sold to another party through a legal document, known as a negotiable instrument. These securities are typically negotiable because they are not tied to a specific issuing entity, but rather to a specific financial instrument, such as a stock, bond, or note.

Negotiable securities are closely related to derivatives, as many derivatives are based on these negotiable securities. Derivatives are financial contracts that derive their value from an underlying asset, such as a stock, bond, or commodity. These contracts can be settled upon maturity, giving the buyer the right to buy or sell the underlying asset at a specified price.

For example, an options contract is a type of derivative that gives the buyer the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell a specific underlying asset at a specified price on or before a certain date. The value of the options contract is derived from the underlying asset, such as a stock or commodity. If the buyer exercises the option, the seller is obligated to sell or purchase the underlying asset at the specified price.

Negotiable securities, such as bonds or notes, can also be used as underlying assets for derivatives. For instance, a bond options contract gives the buyer the right to buy or sell a bond at a specified price on
answers: negotiability is a legal concept that permits free transfer of a security without the requirement of prior consent of the issuer.  that means the issuer must pay the current holder of the security, irrespective of who he is.  negotiability also protects a good faith buyer of the instrument from adverse ownership claims of purported prior holders of the instrument.  it is not related to "negotiating" the price or whatnot.  A negotiable security means the current owner does not have to be concerned about acquiring the asset via a bad chain of title b/c he can always assert that he is a "holder in due course" defense against such claims, and have absolute security in his ownership right over the asset.  securities and derivatives are different.  securities are transferrable instruments representing a direct claim on the issuer for the value of the security, whether debt or equity ownership.  derivatives are bilateral contracts, which can only be entered into with the consent of both parties, and can only be transferred by such consent.  derivatives represent a claim against the parties of to the derivative that depends on some economic reference which is outside of the financial condition of the two parties to the contract, such as interest rates, FX rates, commodity prices, etc.
